title.value: CrossSplit: Mitigating Label Noise Memorization through Data Splitting
title.justification: This is the exact title mentioned at the beginning of the provided text.
title.quote: CrossSplit: Mitigating Label Noise Memorization through Data Splitting

extractions.description: The paper proposes a novel training procedure called CrossSplit to mitigate the memorization of noisy labels. It involves training two neural networks on disjoint parts of the labeled dataset, using cross-split label correction and cross-split semi-supervised training. The method is validated through extensive experiments.

type.justification: The paper involves extensive experimental validation on multiple datasets to verify the proposed method.
type.quote: Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, TinyImageNet and mini-WebVision datasets demonstrate that our method can outperform the current state-of-the-art in a wide range of noise ratios.

name.justification: The paper primarily addresses problems in image classification, which is a core task in computer vision.
name.quote: Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, TinyImageNet and mini-WebVision datasets demonstrate that our method can outperform the current state-of-the-art in a wide range of noise ratios.

name.justification: The datasets used (CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, TinyImageNet, mini-WebVision) are standard benchmarks in image classification tasks.
name.quote: Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, TinyImageNet and mini-WebVision datasets demonstrate that our method can outperform the current state-of-the-art in a wide range of noise ratios.

name.justification: The paper specifically discusses and employs semi-supervised learning techniques within the proposed CrossSplit method.
name.quote: A network trained on one part of the data also uses the unlabeled inputs of the other part.

name.justification: CIFAR-10 is explicitly mentioned as a dataset used for experiments.
name.quote: Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, TinyImageNet and mini-WebVision datasets demonstrate that our method can outperform the current state-of-the-art in a wide range of noise ratios.

referenced_paper_title.value: Learning Multiple Layers of Features from Tiny Images
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference for the CIFAR-10 dataset, originally introduced by Alex Krizhevsky.
referenced_paper_title.quote: CIFAR-10 dataset (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) each contains 50K training and 10K testing 32 × 32 coloured images.

name.justification: CIFAR-100 is explicitly mentioned as a dataset used for experiments.
name.quote: Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, TinyImageNet and mini-WebVision datasets demonstrate that our method can outperform the current state-of-the-art in a wide range of noise ratios.

referenced_paper_title.value: Learning Multiple Layers of Features from Tiny Images

referenced_paper_title.quote: CIFAR-100 dataset (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) each contains 50K training and 10K testing 32 × 32 coloured images.

name.justification: TinyImageNet is explicitly mentioned as a dataset used for experiments.
name.quote: Tiny-ImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015) is a subset of the ImageNet dataset with 100K 64 × 64 coloured images distributed within 200 classes.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference for the TinyImageNet dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Tiny-ImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015) is a subset of the ImageNet dataset with 100K 64 × 64 coloured images distributed within 200 classes.

name.justification: mini-WebVision is explicitly mentioned as a dataset used for experiments.
name.quote: Mini-WebVision (Li et al., 2017a) contains 2.4 million images from websites Google and Flicker and contains many naturally noisy labels.

referenced_paper_title.quote: Mini-WebVision (Li et al., 2017a) contains 2.4 million images from websites Google and Flicker and contains many naturally noisy labels.
